MainCategory.Description: Technical Proficiency: This encompasses the candidate's expertise in required technologies like C#, .NET, SQL, and web technologies (JavaScript, HTML, CSS). It also includes experience with database technologies (SQL Server, T-SQL) and related tools.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Assess through technical interviews, code reviews (if possible), and evaluation of past projects. Verify hands-on experience with the specified technologies. Questions should focus on practical application and problem-solving using these technologies.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Limited or no practical experience with core technologies. Lacks fundamental understanding of required tools and languages.
Some familiarity with the technologies but requires significant guidance. Can perform basic tasks but struggles with complex problems.
Strong working knowledge of the technologies and can independently solve most problems. Demonstrates a good understanding of best practices and efficient coding techniques.
Expert-level proficiency with the technologies. Can architect complex solutions, mentor others, and optimize performance.

MainCategory.Description: Problem-Solving and Troubleshooting Skills: This category assesses the candidate's ability to identify, analyze, and resolve technical issues effectively. It includes the ability to troubleshoot system configurations, debug code, and find solutions for complex problems.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Present candidates with hypothetical problems and ask them to describe their approach to solving them. Evaluate their logical reasoning, ability to break down complex problems, and knowledge of debugging tools and techniques.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Struggles to identify and analyze problems. Unable to effectively troubleshoot even simple issues.
Can identify problems with some guidance but struggles to find effective solutions. Requires assistance with complex troubleshooting scenarios.
Independently identifies and analyzes problems effectively. Able to troubleshoot complex issues and develop creative solutions.
Exceptional problem-solving and troubleshooting skills. Can quickly identify root causes, develop innovative solutions, and prevent future problems.

MainCategory.Description: Software Development Lifecycle (SDLC) Expertise: Assesses understanding and practical experience in all phases of the SDLC, including planning, analysis, design, development, implementation, and maintenance. Also includes experience with Agile development methodologies if applicable.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Ask questions about their experience with each phase of the SDLC and their preferred methodologies. Evaluate their understanding of best practices and their ability to contribute effectively to each stage. Inquire about Agile experience and principles.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Limited understanding of the SDLC. Lacks experience in most phases of the development process.
Basic understanding of the SDLC but requires guidance in most phases. Limited experience with Agile methodologies.
Solid understanding of the SDLC and experience in all phases. Comfortable working with Agile methodologies and contributing effectively to the team.
Deep understanding of the SDLC and extensive experience in all phases. Proficient in Agile methodologies and can mentor others on best practices.

MainCategory.Description: Communication and Collaboration Skills: This category evaluates the candidate's ability to effectively communicate technical information to both technical and non-technical audiences. It also assesses their ability to work collaboratively in a team environment and interface with different stakeholders.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Assess through behavioral interview questions that focus on teamwork, communication, and conflict resolution. Evaluate their ability to explain technical concepts clearly and concisely. Observe their communication style and ability to listen actively.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Poor communication skills. Struggles to explain technical concepts or work effectively in a team.
Adequate communication skills but can be unclear or struggle to work collaboratively. Needs improvement in active listening and conflict resolution.
Strong communication skills. Can explain technical concepts clearly and concisely and works effectively in a team. Good at active listening and conflict resolution.
Exceptional communication and collaboration skills. Can effectively communicate with all stakeholders, build strong relationships, and facilitate teamwork.

MainCategory.Description: Customer Focus and Service Orientation: This category assesses the candidate's dedication to providing excellent customer service and their ability to understand and meet the needs of both internal and external customers.
MainCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Use behavioral interview questions to assess their customer service experience, their ability to handle difficult situations, and their commitment to customer satisfaction. Focus on examples where they went above and beyond to meet customer needs.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Lacks customer focus and demonstrates little interest in providing excellent service.
Some customer service skills but requires guidance in handling difficult situations. Focuses primarily on technical aspects rather than customer needs.
Strong customer service skills and a genuine desire to meet customer needs. Can handle difficult situations effectively and go above and beyond to ensure satisfaction.
Exceptional customer service skills and a passion for providing outstanding support. Proactively identifies and addresses customer needs and is a champion for customer satisfaction.

SubCategory.Description: Code Quality and Maintainability: Assesses the candidate's ability to write clean, well-documented, and maintainable code. This includes adherence to coding standards, use of appropriate design patterns, and creation of unit tests.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Review code samples (if available) and ask questions about their coding practices. Evaluate their understanding of coding standards, design patterns, and unit testing methodologies.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Code is difficult to read and understand. Lacks documentation and adherence to coding standards.
Code is generally readable but could be improved with better documentation and adherence to coding standards.
Code is clean, well-documented, and easy to maintain. Adheres to coding standards and uses appropriate design patterns.

SubCategory.Description: Database Management Skills: Assesses the candidate's experience with database technologies such as Microsoft SQL Server (T-SQL), ODBC, and SQL Reporting Services. This includes the ability to design and implement database schemas, write efficient queries, and optimize database performance.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Ask questions about their experience with database technologies and their ability to solve database-related problems. Evaluate their knowledge of SQL, database design principles, and performance optimization techniques.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Limited database management skills. Struggles to write even basic SQL queries.
Adequate database management skills. Can write basic SQL queries but requires guidance with more complex tasks.
Strong database management skills. Can design and implement database schemas, write efficient queries, and optimize database performance.

SubCategory.Description: Web Technologies Expertise: Evaluates the candidate's proficiency in web technologies such as JavaScript, HTML, CSS, Web Services, ADO, ADO.NET, and IIS.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Assess through questions regarding past web development projects. Test for understanding of key concepts and best practices. Review portfolio examples if available.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Limited understanding of fundamental web technologies. Unable to build basic web pages or applications.
Basic understanding of web technologies and can build simple web pages or applications with guidance.
Strong proficiency in web technologies and can build complex web applications independently.

SubCategory.Description: Learning Agility: Assesses the candidate's ability to quickly learn new technologies and adapt to changing requirements. This includes a willingness to stay up-to-date with the latest trends and advancements in the software engineering field.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Ask about their experience learning new technologies and how they stay current with industry trends. Evaluate their ability to quickly grasp new concepts and apply them to practical problems.

ScoringGuided.Comment: Resistant to learning new technologies and struggles to adapt to changing requirements.
Willing to learn new technologies but requires significant guidance. Adapts slowly to changing requirements.
Eager to learn new technologies and adapts quickly to changing requirements. Proactively seeks out new information and is a continuous learner.

SubCategory.Description: Experience in Public Safety/Public Health (Preferred): Assesses candidate's familiarity with the specific domain the company operates within.
SubCategory.EvaluationStrategy: Ask questions to gauge understanding of domain-specific needs. Evaluate based on previous experience with similar clients or projects.

ScoringGuided.Comment: No relevant experience in the public safety or public health domain.
Some exposure to the public safety or public health domain, but limited practical experience.
Significant experience in developing and supporting software solutions for public safety and/or public health.
